required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Retrospective Evaluation of RMGI/GI Class V Restorations
clinical_study.official_title: Retrospective Clinical Evaluation of RMGI/GI Class V Restorations Placed by Dental Students

brief_summary.textblock: Brief Summary: Retrospective study to evaluate the clinical performance of two restorative materials - glass-ionomer (GI) and resin-modified glass-ionomer (RMGI) materials - in Class V carious and non-carious cervical lesions restored by dental students.

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of this retrospective study was to evaluate the clinical performance of glass-ionomer (GI) and resin-modified glass-ionomer (RMGI) materials in Class V carious and non-carious cervical lesions restored by dental students. Ninety-six (96) restorations performed with either GI (Fuji IX) (n=39) or RMGI (Fuji II) (n=57) were evaluated using the modified USPHS (United States Public Health Systems) criteria by two independent investigators at two follow-up evaluations (two years apart). The Fisher statistical test was used to compare USPHS criteria and examine significant differences by setting p<0.05 for statistical significance and the Kaplan-Meier algorithm was used to calculate the survival probability.

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the presence of Post-Operative Sensitivity of GI and RMGI restorations by asking the patient about the presence of any sensitivity to pressure of the teeth restored by gently tapping on it
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between the 1st follow-up (baseline) and 2nd follow-up evaluation (2 years after)

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the presence or absence of secondary caries of GI and RMGI restorations by using mirrors and probes to clinically assess the restorations
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between the 1st follow-up (baseline) and 2nd follow-up evaluation (2 years after)

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the Anatomic Form of GI and RMGI restorations by using mirrors and probes to clinically assess the restorations
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between the 1st follow-up (baseline) and 2nd follow-up evaluation (2 years after)

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the Color match of GI and RMGI restorations by comparing their shade with the shade of the remainder tooth structure
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between the 1st follow-up (baseline) and 2nd follow-up evaluation (2 years after)

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the Surface Roughness of GI and RMGI restorations by using mirrors and probes to clinically assess the restorations
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between the 1st follow-up (baseline) and 2nd follow-up evaluation (2 years after)

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the Marginal Discolouration of GI and RMGI restorations by using mirrors and probes to clinically assess the restorations
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between the 1st follow-up (baseline) and 2nd follow-up evaluation (2 years after)

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the Marginal Integrity of GI and RMGI restorations by using mirrors and probes to clinically assess the restorations
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between the 1st follow-up (baseline) and 2nd follow-up evaluation (2 years after)

arm_group.description: Resin-modified glass ionomer material, Fuji 2 LC, was used to restore cervical carious and non-carious class V lesions in adult patients of Schulich dental clinic by 3rd and 4th-year dental students.
Glass ionomer material, Fuji 9, was used to restore cervical carious and non-carious class V lesions in adult patients of Schulich dental clinic by 3rd and 4th-year dental students.

intervention.description: Cervical carious lesions were removed with burs and spoon excavators or non-carious cervical lesions were roughened with round carbide burs to remove part of the sclerotic dentin. RMGI (GC Fuji 2) were available in premeasured capsules to facilitate handling and optimize the powder-liquid ratio. Capsules were first activated with one click in the capsule applier, mixed for 10 seconds in an amalgamator and released directly into the cavity preparation, and light-curing was performed for 20 seconds, according to manufacturer's instructions.

Cervical carious lesions were removed with burs and spoon excavators or non-carious cervical lesions were roughened with round carbide burs to remove part of the sclerotic dentin. GI (GC Fuji 9) were available in premeasured capsules to facilitate handling and optimize the powder-liquid ratio. Capsules were first activated with one click in the capsule applier, mixed for 10 seconds in an amalgamator and released directly into the cavity preparation. It was left undisturbed for 3 min. to cure, according to manufacturer's instructions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Carious and non-carious cervical lesions
- Class V Ionomer restorations (RMGI and GIC)
- Restorations placed by 3rd and 4th dental students
Exclusion Criteria:
- Restorations placed outside of the dental school
- Restorations that used other restorative materials

reference.citation: Santos MJ, Ari N, Steele S, Costella J, Banting D. Retention of tooth-colored restorations in non-carious cervical lesions--a systematic review. Clin Oral Investig. 2014;18(5):1369-81. doi: 10.1007/s00784-014-1220-7. Epub 2014 Mar 27. Review.
Neo J, Chew CL, Yap A, Sidhu S. Clinical evaluation of tooth-colored materials in cervical lesions. Am J Dent. 1996 Feb;9(1):15-8.

Franco EB, Benetti AR, Ishikiriama SK, Santiago SL, Lauris JR, Jorge MF, Navarro MF. 5-year clinical performance of resin composite versus resin modified glass ionomer restorative system in non-carious cervical lesions. Oper Dent. 2006 Jul-Aug;31(4):403-8.
van Dijken JW. Retention of a resin-modified glass ionomer adhesive in non-carious cervical lesions. A 6-year follow-up. J Dent. 2005 Aug;33(7):541-7. Epub 2005 Feb 8.

Imbery TA, Namboodiri A, Duncan A, Amos R, Best AM, Moon PC. Evaluating dentin surface treatments for resin-modified glass ionomer restorative materials. Oper Dent. 2013 Jul-Aug;38(4):429-38. doi: 10.2341/12-162-L. Epub 2012 Oct 22.
